docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. JOHN D'ALLARA Rescuing and Calming John D'Allara, a member of the New York Police Department's emergency service office in Harlem, was a rescue specialist on the scene at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. During his 14 years on the job, he pried, cajoled or otherwise extracted a broad array of life forms from danger, dealing with a menagerie of exotic animals. Spider monkeys. Bats. Squirrels. One time, he saved an iguana. But he helped plenty of people, too. ''One time, we had a kid trapped in an elevator, with his head trapped between a beam and the elevator,'' said Sgt. Lee Hom, who worked with Officer D'Allara for five years in the late 1980's and early 90's. ''He kept the kid calm, and we got him out.''

headline.main: A Seeker of Bigger Challenges, a Baseball Lover and a Car Enthusiast
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS

byline.original: These sketches were written by Tara Bahrampour, Kenneth L. Gilpin, Constance L. Hays, Lynette Holloway, Tina Kelley, N. R. Kleinfield, Felicia R. Lee, Dylan Loeb McClain, Andy Newman and Barbara Stewart

docs.lead_paragraph: Trying to pressure the State Senate in the midst of a hard-fought Senate campaign in Manhattan, the Assembly passed three bills today that are liberal favorites, mandating access to female contraceptives and barring discrimination against gays. One of the bills, requiring that health insurers cover a range of services for women, has become a central issue in the Feb. 12 special election for a Senate seat from the Upper East Side, with both the Democrat, Liz Krueger, and the Republican, Assemblyman John Ravitz, calling for its passage. Ms. Krueger, especially, has been hammering away at the issue in advertisements, arguing that the failure to enact the law shows what is wrong with having a mostly Republican, largely male Senate.

headline.main: Bills to Widen Health Care For Women Pass Assembly

docs.abstract: Democratic-controlled New York Assembly passes liberal-backed bills in what is considered effort to boost Liz Krueger in her Senate campaign against Republican Assemblyman John Ravitz; bills mandate health insurance coverage on wide range of services for women, from contraceptives to 'morning after' pills for rape victims; separate measure bars discrimination against gays (M)
